metadata.title: Traction, Mechanical (Lumbar)
description: Spinal traction is the application of tensile forces to the long axis of the spine.(1) Lumbar traction is a treatment for low back pain (LBP) and symptoms associated with mechanical back pathology, such as disc herniation, radiculopathy, and muscle spasm. Traction may be applied mechanically or manually. Mechanical traction generally makes use of a motorized pulley system and a harness attached to the patient’s torso to apply the desired force or weight. The goal is to unload the disc space and muscles in the lumbar spine
indications: Mechanical lumbar traction is used for the treatment of LBP. Specific indications for its use have not been clearly established(1)
reimbursement: Reimbursement will depend on insurance coverage. Variations of mechanical traction that are considered experimental or investigational, such as ambulatory traction and auto-traction,  are not typically covered Indications for procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Patients with cauda equina symptoms (e.g., urinary retention, saddle anesthesia of the perineum, bilateral lower extremity pain/numbness/weakness) should be referred immediately to emergency medicine
Other red flags that indicate prompt referral to emergency medicine are hyperalgesic sciatica and sciatica with severe motor deficits that may represent more severe neurological disease
Red flags that indicate referral back to physician are fever and increased night pain, which can be associated with a spinal tumor or infection such as osteomyelitis
Spinal tumor, infection, unhealed fracture, and DVT
Patients with functional limitations (e.g., poor balance/weight-bearing  status) or comorbidities (e.g., severe cardiopulmonary disease, renal failure, diabetic peripheral neuropathy, dementia)
Signs or symptoms of spinal cord/nerve root compression, bowel/bladder changes, cardiopulmonary distress, dizziness, or lightheadedness

indications for procedure: Indications for using mechanical lumbar traction are controversial, especially since authors of aCochrane systematic review(2) concluded that mechanical traction for LBP is probably not effective

Authors of a more recent (2019) systematic review and meta-analysis  concluded that patients with LBP with herniated disk treated with lumbar traction exhibited significantly morepain reduction and functional improvements than sham or no treatment in the short term, but not in the long term(11)

Mechanical lumbar traction has been advocated to distract the facet joints, increase the space between the vertebrae, enlarge intervertebral foramina, stretch joint capsules and ligaments, and reduce muscle spasm(1) There is insufficient evidence to substantiate most of these proposed effects Authors of a 2019 biomechanical assessment of the changes in the lumbar spine with traction concluded that traction can provide a significant distractive force at the lumbar spine and that patients who experience this force generally have an immediate improvement in pain(12) –Based on biomechanical data provided by 38 Japanese patients with non-specific chronic LBP

Mechanical lumbar traction is commonly used for patients with signs and symptoms of radiculopathy(1) and for treatment of LBP in patients with lumbar disc herniation Lumbar traction may have an effect on the physiology of the intervertebral discs, based upon the results of a systematic review conducted in the United States(9) –Proposed physiologic changes to the discs occur through water diffusion and molecular transport

contraindications: Use of steroids or other medications that can weaken bone
Rheumatoid disorders affecting connective tissue, including rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis
precautions: Being confined in a harness on a traction table in the supine position may be uncomfortable or distressing for patients withclaustrophobia or COPD–It is important for the patient to be able to achieve muscle relaxation to obtain the benefits of the procedure
Patients whose symptoms have increased with traction
Increased pain or peripheralization of symptoms with treatment

a traction table is the most common meth: A traction unit installed at one end produces the tensile force via a cable attached to a motor

The tensile force may be controlled by a simple pulley system or by a device that allows adjustment of various parameters–Computer-controlled  touch screen panels that can program varying tension levels, as well as other variables such as cycletimes and speed of pull, are currently available and allow more sophisticated control of the delivery of traction
An adjustable harness is used to secure the patient’s hips to the cable; another harness secures the thorax to the table
Friction between the body and the support surface is usually eliminated by using a split or sliding table
A patient-controlled  safety switch allows the patient to immediately release the traction if desired

Traction may be applied statically or intermittently–Static traction is applied continuously – recommended for patients with joint and/or nerve root irritability–Intermittent traction is applied for short periods with a rest period in between – recommended for patients with painresulting from muscle spasm
lumbar traction is often performed in su: Researchers comparing the supine and prone position for lumbar traction found that prone lumbar traction resulted in largerintermediate improvements in pain and disability and suggest the prone position should be the first choice(8)–Based on an RCT conducted in Turkey with 125 patients with chronic LBP and lumbosacral nerve root impingement

contraindications precautions to examina: Patients with cauda equina symptoms (e.g., urinary retention, saddle anesthesia of the perineum, bilateral lower extremity pain/numbness/weakness) should be referred immediately to emergency medicine
Other red flags that indicate prompt referral to emergency medicine are hyperalgesic sciatica and sciatica with severe motor deficits that may represent more severe neurological disease
Red flags that indicate referral back to physician are fever and increased night pain, which can be associated with a spinal tumor or infection such as osteomyelitis
Spinal tumor, infection, unhealed fracture, and DVT
Patients with functional limitations (e.g., poor balance/weight-bearing  status) or comorbidities (e.g., severe cardiopulmonary disease, renal failure, diabetic peripheral neuropathy, dementia)
Signs or symptoms of spinal cord/nerve root compression, bowel/bladder changes, cardiopulmonary distress, dizziness, or lightheadedness

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When did symptoms begin? Was onset sudden or gradual? -Were symptoms associated with an injury or particular activity? -Are symptoms improving, worsening, or unchanged? -Does the patient have a history of degenerative disc disease, arthritis, or back problems?

course of treatment.medical management: What treatment has patient received? How has the pain responded to any treatment received?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective in controlling patient’s symptoms? Opioids, NSAIDs, and muscle relaxants (e.g., cyclobenzaprine [Flexeril]) may be prescribed. Epidural steroid and/or lidocaine injections may be administered
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Tests for conditions treated with this procedure may include:
X-ray  to assess for a decrease in disc height and osteophytes
MRI to detect herniated disc pathology
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Document specific areas of back and lower extremities that are affected. Are the neck and upper back affected? Are symptoms unilateral or bilateral?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Patients commonly present with LBP and paresthesias/numbness. Document 24-hour  pain patterns. LBP may also be associated with leg muscle spasms/cramping and weakness
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. In what position does the patient sleep? Document if the patient requires supplemental oxygen or ventilation. Any asthma symptoms?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Inquire about previous back injuries or dysfunction. Has patient used traction before? In addition to asking about redflag  findings (see above), inquire about infectious diseases (e.g., HIV , herpes zoster, Lyme disease), structural deformities of the spine, and, in older patients, mild trauma
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders (including claustrophobia), and orthopedic disordersObtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing, such as upper back or neck pain

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What type of work does the patient do? How is the work environment set up? What home activities and leisure activities does the patient participate in? Risk factors for LBP include poor workstation ergonomics, occupation involving lifting, and poor posture
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: (include limitations with self-care, home management, work, community leisure)
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting) •Anthropomorphic characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI. Measure for leg-length  discrepancy
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document use of any assistive or adaptive devices and reason for their use
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance as indicated. The Berg Balance Scale can be utilized
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pulses and capillary fillingAssess myotomes and dermatomes, and peripheral nerve distributions to differentiate between peripheral neuropathy and radiculopathyDoes the patient use compensatory motions during functional movement? Evaluation of workplace/home/hobby area to determine cause of repetitive stress may be indicated. Look for workstation design that may T708456 for more information
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess functional ability as indicated using standardized tool such as FIM
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait speed and other gait parameters, as applicableAssess mobility of lumbar spine, pelvic region (e.g., sacroiliac joint), and hip joints as indicated. Assess mobility of the upper and lower extremities during functional activities. Do the patient’s posture and flexibility during movements appear limited by pain or restricted joint mobility?
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess abdominal and paraspinal muscle strength within pain tolerance, while avoiding trunk positions and ROM that cause pain. Assess for weakness in the lower extremities using manual muscle testing (MMT)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess spinal alignment and posture of head, neck, shoulders, trunk, pelvis, and lower extremities. Is the posture stooped (head forward and shoulders rounded)? Is the lumbar curve flattened or excessively lordotic? Does the patient list to one side (e.g., away from the painful side)?
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and passive thoracolumbar ROM (forward flexion, lateral flexion, rotation, and extension) and cervical ROM if indicated. Disc herniation typically causes limitation in trunk forward flexion and rotation. Assess for restricted hip rotation; assess tensor fasciae latae, medial hamstrings, posterior adductors, and flexibility throughout lower extremities
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes for hyporeflexia, which may indicate nerve root involvement (L2, L3, L4), Achilles reflex (S1, S2) as indicatedAssess ADLs as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess temperature, light touch, and deep pressure sensation. Note dermatomal distribution as indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisReproduction of radicular symptoms with stretching of sciatic nerve indicates nerve root involvement. The SLR is sensitive for radiculopathy but has low specificity. Various versions of the SLR exist. The classic version is described below -With patient relaxed in supine position, both knees extended, foot in neutral dorsiflexion, the examiner raises the affected leg, keeping knee extended -Once symptoms are reported, the therapist maintains leg elevation and then passively dorsiflexes the ankle and/or flexes the cervical spine to further sensitize the test -Test is positive if symptoms in low back are reproduced with elevating leg -Specificity increases if the SLR test of the unaffected leg also reproduces symptoms (called “crossover sign”)A patient’s response to gentle manual traction may provide an indication of how mechanical traction will be tolerated(1) -With patient in supine, knees flexed and feet on plinth (crook lying), examiner places hands behind patient’s knees and gently pulls caudally -With patient in supine and knees extended, examiner grips at ankles and gently pulls both legs caudallyPatient-completed questionnaire that gives a subjective percentage score of level of disability -Appropriate for use with acute or chronic LBP -Useful for severe persistent disabilityAssesses self-rated disability caused by LBP -Most sensitive for patients with mild to moderate disability
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Assess for signs of upper motor lesions (e.g., hypertonicity, hyperreflexia, clonus, unsteady gait, positive Babinski sign) and lower motor lesions (e.g., weakness, muscle wasting, hyporeflexia or areflexia, hypotonicity)

other: The therapist should discuss with the patient the sensations to be expected during traction. The patient should be told to notify the therapist immediately if pain increases(1)
Patients should be provided a safety switch to immediately release the traction or a call bell to call for assistance
The therapist should observe the traction being applied and the patient’s response for several minutes when the session begins before leaving the patient unsupervised
The traction dosage (amount of tension, duration, and cycle duration with intermittent traction) should be conservative initially and gradually increased based on patient’s response(1)
The amount of tension applied should not cause or increase symptoms

Hot packs may be applied in conjunction with traction to facilitate muscle relaxation. Extreme caution is advised if hot pack is placed underneath patient while traction is applied, as patient’s inability to adjust body weight can cause burns(1)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: LBP with signs and symptoms of disc herniation, including radiating lower extremity symptoms, is the most commonly listed diagnosis;(1) stiffness related to muscle spasm or facet joint pathology; reduction of symptoms with manually applied traction is also mentioned(1)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedist or physiatrist for medical management of pain or muscle spasms. Peri-radicular  nerve-root  steroid injections may reduce sciatic pain Neurologist for persistent radicular or neurological symptoms Trained manual physical therapist, osteopath, or chiropractor for manual manipulation of lumbar spine Acupuncturist or pain management for intractable pain
treatment summary: Mechanical traction is not designed to be a stand-alone  treatment.It should be performed as a secondary treatment, with manual therapy and exercise being first-line  treatment(1)

Neither the 2016 National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guidelines(14) nor the 2017 American College of Physicians guidelines(15) recommends the use of mechanical traction for LBP with radicular pain

Authors of a 2013 Cochrane review on various forms of lumbar traction concluded that there was strong evidence that traction as a single treatment is no more effective than placebo, sham, no treatments, or other treatments for patients with LBP with or without sciatica(2)

Authors of a 2019 systematic review of the effects of mechanical traction on patients with herniated intervertebral discs concluded that traction causes short-term  pain reduction and functional improvement but is not effective in the long-term(11) –Based on 7 RCTs with 403 adult patients with LBP and herniated disc confirmed by MRI or CAT scan –The authors did not see evidence to support the idea that lumbar traction reduces herniated disc size

Results from an RCT involving patients with LBP and signs of nerve root compression indicated that adding mechanical traction to extension exercises provided no added benefit(16) –Based on a U.S. study of 120 patients recruited from PT clinics where patients received up to 12 treatments during a 6-week  period –No differences in pain and disability were seen at 6 weeks, 6 months, and 1 year after treatment

The addition of mechanical traction to medications already being taken improved pain, anxiety, depression, and quality of life in patients with backache(17) –Based on study conducted in Egypt of 47 patients with backache who were matched with 48 healthy controls –Patients with backache received infrared radiation for 10 minutes followed by 20 minutes of intermittent traction at up to half body weight. Patients were treated for 4 weeks but it was not clear how often –Outcome measures were pain, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), and Short-Form  36 Health Survey (SF-36) –All measures improved significantly in patients with backache –Patients who were treated beyond the 4 weeks saw no added benefit

According to research, various combinations of treatment modalities in conjunction with lumbar traction have been reported to be effective in the treatment of LBP caused by lumbar disc herniation and/or nerve root involvement, including hamstring stretching(4)

Results of a 2015 study in South Korea showed that effects on intervertebral discs can be visualized with MR imaging taken during traction(7) –Continuous traction on lumbar discs resulted in changes in disc shape, disc reduction with opening in the vertebral disc, reduction in herniation volume, separation of disc and nerve root, and widening of the fact joint –Forty-eight  patients with lumbar disc herniations (13 men, 35 women) participated in the study –Subjects were treated with continuous lumbar traction. MR images were taken prior to traction and at 10-minute intervals throughout a 30-minute  session of 30kg traction –Limitations of the study include lack of a control group, force of traction was the same for all subjects despite weight, and there was no long-term  follow-up  of the patients to determine if effects of traction lasted beyond treatment time
Researchers found that prone traction combined with conventional physical therapy resulted in decreased pain and disability as compared to supine traction(8)

Research on alternative forms of traction –In an RCT conducted in Poland, investigators found that significantly better analgesic effects were obtained in a group of patients with chronic LBP treated with Saunders lumbar traction than in a control group(5) -Saunders lumbar traction is a pneumatic traction device marketed for home use -The study included 140 patients who were randomly assigned to receive axial Saunders traction applied to the lumbar part of the vertebral column or pharmacological treatment (control) -Both groups showed reduced pain and improved function, but the results were significantly better in the traction group –Lumbar extension traction (in which a posterior padded belt is placed under the patient’s lower back) in addition to stretching exercises and infrared radiation has been reported to improve spine sagittal alignment and decrease pain and disability in patients with chronic mechanical LBP(3) -Based on an RCT conducted in Egypt with 80 patients with chronic mechanical LBP and definite hypolordosis randomly assigned to a group receiving stretching exercises and infrared radiation or a group receiving lumbar extension traction as well as stretching exercises and infrared radiation. Treatment was 3 times a week for 10 weeks -The main outcome variable was the lumbar lordotic curve, measured via X-ray  before and after intervention -Secondary outcome measures included pain (V AS) and disability (Oswestry Low Back Disability Questionnaire) -There was a significant difference between the groups with respect to lumbar lordotic curve, thoracic kyphosis, sacral slope, and C7 plumb line distance -Pain and disability decreased in both groups –Other variations of lumbar traction include auto-traction, “spinal decompression,” and inversion(1) -Auto-traction  uses a patient’s own body weight and muscle strength to provide distractive forces -However, activation of paraspinal musculature when performing auto-traction  tends to preclude generation of effective distraction force(1) -Spinal decompression has been promoted as a novel approach, although the distinction between decompression and traction is reportedly based largely on technicalities related to U.S. FDA approval and marketing(1) -Inversion devices allow gravity-assisted  traction. The patient secures the pelvis and lower extremities into a frame and then the body position is inverted, allowing the upper trunk weight to distract the spine(1) -Increases in lumbar intervertebral space immediately following inversion have been documented(1) -Adverse effects of the inverted position include increased intraocular pressure, alterations in blood pressure, and anxiety while inverted -Not recommended for patients with a history of dizziness, vertigo, or hypertension –Supine mid-abdominal  traction is another form of traction that allows a load to be applied to the anterior abdomen while the patient is supine with knees flexed(10) –Low force traction (10% body weight) was found to be just as effective as high force (50% body weight) in reducing radicular pain and functional impairment and improving well-being(18) -Based on an RCT conducted in France involving 17 subjects with acute lumbar sciatica secondary to disc herniation -Patients received 10 treatments in 2 weeks -Benefits were maintained after 2 weeks follow-up

See Description, Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  LBP of mechanical origin, with or without lower extremity symptomsDecrease pain and leg symptomsLumbar traction _ As a component of a physical therapy treatment program that includes back education and advice _ _ Position may be in supine or proneStart with conservative dose in terms of force applied and duration of treatment, and increase based on patient’s responsePatients who obtain relief with lumbar traction may benefit from a home traction unit _ _ Recent advances in home lumbar traction designs have made them more practical(1) _ _

decreased back and leg pain: V AS, numeric pain rating scale

maintenance or prevention: Education on proper ergonomics and body mechanics and how to modify tasks that increase pain
A home exercise program to maintain or improve impairments should be prescribed
